name: Scents of Memory
description:
In this session of Reader’s Bloc, we’ll explore two texts—The Book of Everlasting Things by Aanchal Malhotra and Smell by Radhika Jha—both exploring smell as not just a sense, but as a conduit for memory, love, identity and belonging. 

Malhotra’s The Book of Everlasting Things follows a perfume maker in pre-partition India, where different scents become the legacy passed through generations, carrying with it familial love and a lot of history; while Jha’s Smell, tells the story of a young brown woman who navigates identity and alienation in postcolonial, diasporic France. 

This session is conducted as part of our engagements for the MAP Youth Collective. The Collective is a community for young people (18-25 year olds) to engage with the arts and culture sector. The collective is for, of and by young people — to explore our shared identities and interests through art.

name: Love Letters - Ninna Preetiya, Naanu!
description:
In an age of instant messages and disappearing stories, the play "Love Letters: Ninna Preetiya Naanu" invites you to pause, reflect, and turn the pages of the past—one heartfelt letter at a time.

This poignant, original Kannada play explores the depth of a lifelong connection between two people bound by nostalgia, affection, and all the words left unsaid. Imagine scrolling through a lifetime of messages—not through DMs, but through yellowing pages, hurried handwriting, and tear-stained notes. From scribbled notes in school notebooks to confessions that arrive too late, the play spans decades of friendship and almost-love.

It's a journey through innocence, longing, and the quiet ache of missed chances—narrated through letters that become both a timeline and a testament to what was, and what might have been.

This performance is in conjunction with the exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar.

name: Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar
description:
This guided walk of the exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar, gives audiences a peek into the making of the exhibition. Join us to gain a deep understanding of the artist and his journey to becoming one of India’s most iconic modernist voices

The exhibition invites visitors to pause and reflect, observe and be inspired. Experience the profound inner world of Ram Kumar, as we mark the centenary this extraordinary artist.

name: Memory Maps
description:
Inspired by Ram Kumar’s works and the city of Bangalore, this workshop reflects on personal and collective memories - exploring themes of belonging, migration and the urban experience.

Led by Arzu Mistry and Aliyeh Rizvi, co-founders of The Memory Maps Project, this interactive workshop invites you to create your own personal Map of Memories. Following a walkthrough of the exhibition - Ram Kumar and You, participants will be guided to reflect, share, map and draw their responses to the city.

This performance is in conjunction with the exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar.

name: The Art of Language
description:
Poet, playwright, and academic Mamta Sagar joins Arundhati Ghosh for an intimate conversation on poetry, translation, and the intersections of word and image. Exploring her creative process and her forays into visual art, Mamta reflects on how language transforms into texture, rhythm, and form, offering audiences a rare glimpse into the evolving journey of her work.

This talk is in collaboration with Ananya Dhrishya.

name: Make at MAP
description:
Boo! Did we scare you—Good! This Halloween-themed Make at MAP session is all about facing your fears. Taking cues from classic Bollywood horror film posters, create your very own poster starring your deepest fears.

Make @ MAP is a series that allows you to explore our collection in an engaging and hands-on manner. These sessions allow you to create and take home a special souvenir of your visit. It is perfect for all ages — so bring your friends and family and get ready to make some art! No experience is necessary, just a willingness to have fun and experiment with new materials.
